The essential link between Mass Effect and Mass Effect 3.   Mass Effect 2 is less focused on the general story background, but puts building a team and relationships into the focus of its story line. Apart from the introduction of the 'Collectors', there's isn't much added to what has been learned about the reapers in Mass Effect 1.  Mass Effect 2 is best enjoyed with an imported save game, giving away bits and pieces about what happened to all the colorful persons the payer met in the first game.   Combat has been drastically simplified, giving way less emphasize on building the character and outfitting them with gear. With speed of the encounters picking up, the tactical impact of squad utilization has been dropped seomwhat in favor of putting the player's reaction time more into focus. It's not necessarily a bad thing, but won't appeal to those who wish for a less hectic approach to combat.  While enjoying ME 2 greatly at the first time, I personally didn't find the second playthrough of ME 2 as rewarding as it felt for ME 1, because of the rather thin story development. While building relationships with the NPCs feels rewarding, it comes somewhat short in terms of depths. Less squad mates with more character development would have been preferable.  Bottom line: Essential to (re)live the trilogy, but feels slightly like a stretch for those who already know about the dramatic developments of ME 3.  PS: Don't miss updating the game with a HD texture modification! Due to technical limitations the developers did include low res textures only! The screenshots I have taken showcase HD textures for all squadmates.    IMPORTANT:      Despite being published by EA, Mass Effect 2 DOES NOT require Origin to play. BUT: You are able to register your Steam copy of ME 2 at Origin as well, which enables you to download the DLC you're already eligible for by purchasing the special edition of the game.

The second installment of the ME franchise, and another all-time favorite of mine.  The gameplay, which was the flaw of the previous ME, has been massively (hue hue) revamped, making it a more enjoyable shooter, although (and is mostly the case in higher difficulty settings), you'll find yourself digging through the multiple layers of protection your enemies have (Biotic barrier, armor and shield, some enemies combine two if not 3 of them), but this is where powers shine. Much like the first installment, the game has both tech powers (hacking, burning, things like that) and biotic powers ('super-powers' if you want), you MUST make use of these powers in a smarter way.  The inventory management part has been for the most part removed, all that is left for you to do is simply chose your squadmates' weapons and yours, and customize your own armor (you can only change how your squadmates' armor looks like now, and there ain't much choice). The whole weapon modding mechanics has been scraped as well, ammunition mods are now powers inherent to your class (if it has any), and weapons can be upgraded through research. Same goes for the skill trees, their size has been greatly reduced which allows for a greater understanding of what is what and what does what. With that, the game is a lot more simplified, perhaps for the best.  The storyline and storytelling remains awesome, and the fact that choices made in the previous game get carried over is just great.  In conclusion another hit by Bioware. Do keep in mind that you'll have to count at least 30 hours + (if playing on Insanity, and if you give enough of a damn about the storyline) in order to complete this other epic journey. Also, it is best to have played the first game, not just because you can shape up the world of the games to come, but because you get a greater understanding of what's going on, who's on and of course... What is what.  Hell, it's a must! Why play this game in the first place if you don't give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the story.

The second, and in my opinion, the best game in the Mass Effect trilogy.   Improving upon the first game in every way, but NOT dumbing down many gameplay elements, it introduces a new, dramatic, exciting story full of unpredictable twists and turns, making it look like a spectacular, highly interactive space opera movie.  The driving sections around barren planets from ME1 are gone (and replaced with planet scanning, and new driving sections if you own the appropriate DLC), even trivial sidequests have great direction, and seem important even though they do not tie in directly to the main story line.   I loved the introduction of clearly Lovecraftian horror elements in the story, something that the third game completely ignored. The Reapers, ancient enemies of all sentient life, are basically intergalactic gods, dangerous even when destroyed, their huge spaceship-like bodies able to brainwash would-be explorers millenia after their 'death'. It feels you're fighting truly unknown and horrifying adversaries, which gives the game a very unique atmosphere.  The characters are unique and believable, dialogue is well-written and interesting, and it's hard to leave the game once you've started playing.  Playing ME1 is pretty much a requirement prior to playing ME2, though- after all, it is a continuation of a great storyline.  The end is well-rounded, and even though it implies a sequel, it doesn't leave you hanging from a cliff, so to say :)  Recommended!   P.S. Getting the DLC for this game is a relatively hard process nowadays, thanks to EA's greedy, unoptimized and ham-handed decisions. Basically, you'll have to activate your ME2 copy on Origin, buy DLC on Origin, download them through Bioware Social website, and install them manually after installing (and running) ME2.   Why would you do all that?  Some DLCs (such as the Arrival and Lair of the Shadow Broker) have story-critical content, along with additional quality gameplay, which adds a lot of new content to the game. If you turn out to be a real fan of the game and hooked on the story of Commander Shepard, you WILL need to play through these additional stories, as they cover some moments heavily referenced in the sequel, Mass Effect 3.  EA's way of selling DLC means they NEVER go on a sale, so be prepared to dish out some serious cash for them (individual DLC prices can be several times higher than the price of the base game!!!) and only purchase them if you're REALLY interested in the story.   Also, you can safely ignore the 'equipment' DLC, as they are really only a money grab, selling you variations of weapons or cosmetic 'upgrades' to your team for real money.

I feel that comparisions to the original game is necessary when writing a review for Mass Effect 2, so here it goes:  1. Like Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2 is a story-rich 3rd-person FPS where you play as Commander Sheperd. However, the story was not as captivating as ME1 and it seemed that I spent more time assembling and gaining the loyalty of my crew than on the main campaign, which in retrospect was pretty short and straightforward.  2. The combat system was an improvement from ME1, where it was much easier to utilise abilities (both yours and your squad's) by binding them to the numerical keys. However, combat got really repetitive after a while. The hacking/ bypassing system was also an improvement, although mostly unnecessary and also repetitive.   3. Anyone who played the original game would remember the dreadfully long elevator rides. Thankfully, ME2 had smoother transitioning and also higher quality cut-scenes which were very enjoyable.  4. Like in ME1, it was possible to flirt/ develop relationships with a number of crewmates, although you would have to complete your target's loyalty quest before you could express interest. However, I was disappointed when Liara (ME1 character) could not be recruited into my squad, even though she did make an appearance in the game.  I gave ME1 a rating of 9.5/10 only because of the elevator rides. While ME2 was a good game, it seemed to be lacking in story and also its descent into repetitiveness.   8.5/10

First Review in my career. I have more like 60 hours as the internet went out for a while as oppossed to the 40+ that is shown. I have played through the game 2 times once (and most recently) as a male Shepard and another as a female Shepard. Copnstructive critism is wlcome as well as advice because I plan to review some of the other games I have. So please, enjoy.   Disputably, this is the superior game in the Mass Effect Series. Personally I hold this opinion, but do NOT just buy this game. In order to get totally immersed in the story and develop connections to the characters, purchase the original Mass Effect and possibly Mass Effect 3 (but use Origin at your own peril).   The story itself is extremely engaging. Traveling the galaxy and assembling a suicide squad is interesting as each character is found in different places and missions associated with the character's loyalty to you are also unique. I never once came across a moment when I thought 'I've seen this before'. While enemies are mild repeats (you will be fighting armored aliens, sheilded ones, boss ones, and various types of mechs), the NPCs are always very interesting even if they are flat.   The role-playing aspects of the game are handled well. When starting the game, you can choose between 6 different types of combat styles which range from being a pure biotic (using magic), an infiltrator (turning invisible), and being a soldier (regular combat grunt/bad***). Each of those classes have 5 upgradable abilities that either give you interesting ammo mods or special attacks like slamming a person to the ground or turning invisible for a short time. On top of that once you chose your character class, you can select another special ability from a list. Every time you level up, you recieve one point for spending it on abilities. Initially, all of them cost 1 point and once they are upgraded, they incriment (go up) by 1. At the end of the skill bar for each skill you can chose a significant bonus ability. For an ammo mod, this could be giving yourself an upgraded form of it or allowing your entire squad to partake in it. The latter thing I find most useful because I tend to hang back and pick off enemies from range and let my squand soak up most of the enemy fire.   Speaking of combat, I love this 3rd-person style. It leans heavily on cover and utilizing the abilities of your allies. You can direct your 2 squad members simply pressing a key (one per member). To use your abilities and your squad member's, you hold down a button and select the ones you wish to use. Your team can deploy at most 3 separate abilities (one per person). Aside from that, regular combat with guns is point, aim, shoot. You can hold a maximum of 6 guns, however this depends on which class you pick in the beginning. The adept class doesn't even carry weapons while the soldier can hold all 6. You can have a sniper rifle, assult rifle, shotgun, speical weapon (missile launcher,mini-nuke launcher, etc), pistol, and submachine gun. Acquring of these weapons range from finding them in levels, recieving them, and making them. There is melee combat, but it is rather sloppy. If you were to use it (which I don't) you leave yourself open to enemy fire which will destory you if you aren't in cover even on the easiest difficulty. The enemy A.I. is capable of flanking, putting down suppressive fire, and charging indescriminantly, so it always keeps you on your toes. Sometimes the enemies get stuck behind obstacles, but the pathing for them are solid. They use cover and can go through your suad members quickly.   The graphics are exceptional even for a game from 2010. The textures are good, but in combat it really shines. The laser beams, mass-effect bullets, and ammo mods are a sight to behold when they are flying everywhere. The sounds are also good. The soundtrack is also pretty good.   The place where this game falls short is the map system. Like from the previous game, you travel across the galaxy using Mass Relays. That is carrried over, but the actual physical exploration of planets and moons from the previous installment is scraped in favor of a mining minigame which is tedious to do for an extended period of time. It is also worthwhile though as the resources you get from mining is used for upgrades which are found in the course of missions and from purchashing them.   The upgrades are rather significant improvements which range from increased damage to reduced cooldowns to even additional equipment for the ship. I highly recommend consulting your team for ship upgrades because they will make the difference between life and death in the late game. Some do cost a lot of stuff, so you will get aquainted with the mining monstrosity.   However, this is overshadowed by the characters you interact with. While I briefly went over this in the beginning, I feel I must describe how great it is. Every character on your ship have a story, opinions, and remarks about your progress. And yes, the infamous romance options are back and 'better' than ever. I will let you explore them to see for yourself because I have not explored them yet.   The lore is wonderfully explained to you through the codex, accessable via the pause menu. As you interact with more things, the condex articles explain everything.   Overall, I give this game a 9 out of 10. The strong character customization/upgrading system teamed with the strong graphics, good teamwork elements, and the immaculate NPC collection are what make this game a must-own for Sci-Fi fans. If you are bored by generic first-person shooters and want a more engaging combat system, this is a good game to look into.   I know that there is a multiplayer to the game as well, but I have not exlpored it. I would suggest skipping it. To me, this is a single-player experience through and through.   So long and good luck.

Pros: -Characters and their interactions with each other. As you build your team, you stumble upon some very interesting people. The best aspect of the game was getting to know everybody between missions, hearing their stories, and delving deeper into the Mass Effect universe. Especially Garrus with all of his calibrations, which is everything he wants to talk about. Then there’s the fact that you’re able to romance some of the crew members. I really felt like I was invested in and torn between some of them. Whether it was flirty Kelly, shy Tali, or (insert your description of) Miranda.  -Loyalty and crew missions. One of the reasons why you do care about the crew is permadeath. In order to get all of the crew out alive, you have to go on some loyalty missions. As you get to know everybody, crewmembers will tell you that there’s some personal problem they would like solved. Loyalty missions were the best kind of side mission because they weren’t random things to do. There was a sense of purpose—gaining a more meaningful understanding of the crew. All of them played out like a good movie should, with everybody gaining some type of character growth and a solid resolution.  -Combat is decent and can be challenging. While it reinvented the wheel, I wasn’t bored senseless. In fact, there were a few parts that I had a difficult challenge. This one part of saving Garrus took me at least ten or so tries. Mostly due to the fact that enemies will use cover effectively, (generally) work as a group, and at times actually attempt to flank you.  Mixed Bag: -Dumbing down of rpg elements. It really seemed like there was much less of a focus on weapon diversity and putting together your gear. While it doesn’t kill the game, it certainly does make it more confusing when you buy upgrades. The upgrades tell you that it will do XYZ% more damage, but there’s no indication of how much that would be.  -Interiors seem a lot smaller. The Citadel is pathetically tiny compared to the original. And the same could be said of a lot of the places you visit. They felt small and often very linear. I really wanted to explore some of these places, but to no avail.  -No Mako, scanning only. The Mako is totally gone, which also felt like exploration was severely curtailed, and has been replaced with scanning planets. While this may on paper sound like getting resources has been streamlined—it isn’t. I did have this Minecraft mentality of collecting everything everywhere, but It’s downright boring a tedious after the fifth or so planet that you’ve scanned in the same system. By the time that you’re done with scanning every planet you’ll have an astronomically huge collection of resources. Overall: Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece. There was not a lot of time that I felt like I was disengaged from the story or that I was bored doing ho-hum quests. The mythos of the universe, the strength of the characters, and the story is what elevates this game into what I consider to be near legendary. 9.5/10

I just finished my first playthrough of ME2. I could immediately see why it's such a classic trilogy in the gaming world. It added a lot of dynamics to the game which were and still are somewhat uncommon in shooters. It's very similar to a Gears of War combat system, except with the ability to pause, review your surroundings, and command your allies to execute attacks or movements. That alone added an element of strategy with an excellent and unique cover system.  The character development was also a treat. I was always running to my allies, wanting to talk to them and uncover their individual opinions and pasts. Each character was likeable in their own way, having a bit of complexity that never fit into a stereotypical mold, and a visual appearance that was distinctly original.  The dialogue options and the lasting effects of choices, especially if you've played through the first game, made the dialogue more interesting. It's funny because the actual gameplay is seldom affected by your choices, much to the regret of many ME3 players. Without the expectation of some grandiose conclusion based on my actions, I was able to see the game for what it was. It's a present experience, not a build-up, and it does it extremely well. Like a good book when you're done, you wish that you have that anticipation back that you had as you read it. It just proves that the story was very compelling.  My only complaint was the research gathering system, which took several hours of my time for a very uninteresting mechanic added ot the game. I'll admit that it adds a reward for exploration in that sense, and it gives a way to interact with things in space, but the very limited scope of it is more of a time sink to justify the upgrades. I'd rather that the more you used certain characters, the more experience it added to the upgrade. It would've given incentive to change up your party members and have them use different weapons.  I'd personally give this game a 8.5 / 10. I really enjoyed the story and gameplay, which were captivating enough for me to actually finish a game for once, I felt like the experiences were linear, although very original and interesting, full of background information on each character and always relevant to some immediate concern. I never wanted to get something 'over with.' Every part of the game was enjoyable (except a certain Hacking mission in a city). I think that if the game incorporated some of the last mission choices into other areas of the game, it would've made things feel a lot more dynamic and weighty. Excellent game, looking forward to ME4!

Mass Effect 2 is a great game in many respects.  It boasts memorable locations. Be it the crime hub of Omega, Asari corporate haven of Illium or the Citadel Wards, all of them feature meticulous attention to detail, making all of them believable, lively and interesting to explore.  It boasts great characters, each with their unique custom-tailored missions. No longer it feels like tedious shoot 'em up of ME1 in the same three-template outposts (underground base, two-story warehouse or a cave). Surroundings, goals and flow of those missions will make almost all of them stand out as much as Noveria or Feros did. While custom (!) tense brooding music (and rightly so - a lot of plots are about something very messed up and troubling) only sharpens the experience.  The combat itself was greatly improved too. The highlight is probably the sniper rifle wielding Infiltrator experiencing a massive positive change compared to ME1.  Some notable gameplay changes worth mentioning include weapon heat, bullets, weapon and armor customization. ME2 introduces bullets (you have to worry about picking clips up, particularly if you rely on a sniper rifle or a pistol in the scenario involving fighting waves or simply a large host of enemies) and removes all customization and overheating. I can understand the reasons well enough - let's admit it, 99% of the people were using the same mods and bullets anyways, the console interface of ME1 was extremely uncomfortable to navigate while outfitting each of your companions, and having to worry about bullets does change the combat somewhat. Yet still it feels too streamlined and sterile.  Exploration in Mako was completely removed, replaced with planet scanning. Personally, I've always found Mako roaming tedious and needlessly time-consuming, but a lot of people seem to miss it.  ME2 also features a new system of gaining experience. You are now rewarded for completing missions, which means that you don't have to worry about doing something gamey to milk maximum experience.  I have only two personal gripes with new features. The first one is about purchasing new abilities. Each ability has only 4 levels, each subsequent one costing more. By the end of the game you get to spend your points to purchase new levels very rarely - once every 2-3 missions. And no, they don't feel rewarding enough to justify the wait. The second one is that the number of available weapons is reduced to 2-3 per slot (which could be augmented with DLCs, but DLC weapons usually suffer from being OP, so no joy anyways).  (What's interesting is that ME3 managed to find a great middleground between streamlining of ME2 and overabundance of ME1. Weapon mods and weapon variety are back, missions consist of subobjectives, each rewarding you with xp, and you have more abilities with more levels in each. All of it smoothes out the gameflow.)  Mass Effect 2 isn't without its flaws of course. And the biggest one in my opinion demolishes the idea that Drew Karpyshyn would've definitely made a huge difference for writing ME3. The main plot of the second game is shambles. Worse yet, it was made even more pointless by the Arrival DLC and ME3. Fortunately it is comprised of only a handful of missions, and the last one at least gives you tense rewarding action and cinematics. But as long as you can turn off your brain (fortunately Shepard displays this capacity all too often already :p ) and just blindly do whatever the Illusive Man wants you to - you'll be fine. The rest of the game is totally worth it. So much so I'm currently riding ME1 one more time to get a lvl 60 import just because I enjoyed ME2 immensely and want more of it.

The story, characters, and beautiful writing continue in Mass Effect 2 and by the end of this series, you will have encountered some of the most lovable and memerable characters in any video game. There are very few games which can be described as having truly perfected their formula. One could say that Mario and Sonic perfected the platformer, that mario galaxy perfected the 3D platformer, perhaps even that games like GTA: San Andreas perfected the open-world formula. Mass Effect 2 is a game that has created its own formula by delicately fusing RPG elements with third-person shooter gameplay, and the result is simply pure perfection.  The game picks up a few years after the first Mass Effect game and revolves around the protagonist from the first game, John (or Jane) Shepard, who after waking up from a coma and being essentially brought back from the dead by a shadowy organisation named Cerberus must stop an invasion of deadly aliens known as the Collectors, who are abducting entire colonies of humans for some unknown purpose. To do this, he must assemble a team and travel beyond the Omega 4 Relay, from which no ship has ever returned. As he recruits new allies and old friends for his suicide mission, Shepard makes new discoveries which reveal more and more of the mysterious Collectors' nature and goals.  The story in this game is absolutely amazing. How the plot progresses depends partly on the actions that Shepard took in the first Mass Effect, so I highly reccommend playing that first before this. The rest is decided through the game's morality system - 'Paragon' choices make Shepard a much more noble, just character, whereas 'Renegade' choices make him bolder, harsher and colder. This allows for a different experience and different character developments for Shepard depending on what choices the player makes throughout the game and its predecessor - anything that you do could change the course of the whole game. And when you reach the ending, I absolutely guarantee that you will be on the edge of your computer chair with tension. Also returning from Mass Effect 1 is the ability to start a romantic relationship with one of the characters on board the ship. This has little effect on the storyline itself but it's kind of cute to see Shepard finding love.  As for the gameplay, Mass Effect 2 builds upon the starndard third person shooter formula with some innovative features, for instance Shepard and his team can use various abilities in battle, including various technological abilities, different weapon ammo types and 'biotics' - psychic-like abilities which can be used for both offence and defence. This seems to make battles flow much more as you swictn betwnn shooting and using your powers to find the best way of dispatching your enemy.  The game has a 'loyalty mission' system, wherein you can gain special missions from particular characters, and if you complete these missions you will unlock an extra outfitm and extra power and that character's 'loyalty' - in the endgame thhis will become very important, so after you start receiving these missions, try to avoid other missions until you have recruited everyone and completed all of their loyalty missions. Shepard can also purchase upgrades for his allies and for his ship, the Normandy - these will also be much needed in the endgame.  All in all, Mass Effect 2 is hard to describe with any other word other than its own title. With an awe-inspiring story, action-packed gameplay and endless replay value, no self-respecting gamer should pass it up.

Mass Effect 2 is the second installment to the Mass effect franchise. While Shepard’s story can begin here, I recommend that players play the first Mass Effect instalment. It greatly enhances the players experience of the story. Mass Effect 2 in undoubtedly a great game with reviews to match, but it has to join that list of games I hate, but still believe are great games and would defiantly play them again. I completed my play through on Veteran, since I felt the default was a little too low. The story of Mass Effect 2 definatly is the pinnacle of the franchise, with a strong opening, mid and end game. You decisions are impactful and extensive. The characters are more diverse and each has a story Shepard can partake in. The games complex mechanics from Mass Effect have been simplified for the better. Levels are streamlined and feel more accessible. Overall I'd say Mass Effect 2 provides the greatest story satisfaction. Players will walk out with what they put into the story. Now, when it comes to gameplay I'm not sure what to say. I want to be somewhat objective about games I play, but still give my opinion. I feel I need to go back a play the game again, but overall I'd say Mass Effect 2 was the most unfair of the three games. What I mean is that I'm one of those people who'll try the game on insanity just to see if I can do it. I couldn't, not because I was terrible at the game, but I felt that Shepard just could do the complex moves he needed to do. Besides that the Squad AI is terrible and dies very quickly putting all the heat on you, which usually mean that you die. It's the first time I've begun to play on an insanely high difficulty and found it unrealistic and unrewarding. What's weird is that I found Mass Effect 3 was possible on insanity, though it required a lot of restarts. Basically I think Mass Effect 2 is one of the mechanically bad games I've played. Everything works, but higher difficulties reveal that the combat and movement are basically broken and poorly implemented. All this said it’s a fantastic game overall and I highly recommend it along with the entire mass effect series. Mass Effect 3 (it’s sequel) is only available on Origin which is run by EA Games.

It's hard to pinpoint exactly what makes Mass Effect 2 such a good game. It has that magic spark that all developers strive for, but very few achieve. It could be in the myriad worlds, innovative species and unbelievably detailed lore, or the fantastically designed and written characters, every single one perfectly imagined. Or it could be the agonising, heart-rending decisions you must make, the consequences spiralling far into the next game with you.  Every facet of this game gleams with such brilliance, it's hard to play it just once. And the beauty of it is, it ENCOURAGES you to reply it in a different way, every time. Want to play a hardcore soldier, intimidating and coercing others through force and violence? Do it. Want to play as an Engineer with god-like biotic powers, helping everyone you come across? Do it. And the next time, experiment with yet another style.  Of the Mass Effect series, one of the most intense aspects is persistent effects of your choices. Kill somebody in the first game? They're gone for good. Anger or charm somebody in the second game? They will remember your treatment in the third installment. This gives the series such fantastic replayability that I have completed the trilogy more than 7 times (granted, on console) and each time, I discover a something new.  It's been six years since Mass Effect 2's release, and in six years more, I will still be playing it. It's never too late to experience this masterpiece for the first time.
